The entire code is in there including the code to start a new $ XRP Ledger. From the command line, execute “rippled --start” and a brand new ledger is started. That’s actually documented in the code and the online documentation provided by @ Ripple. https://github.com/ripple/rippled https://twitter.com/f0nta1n3/status/977959594776506369 …

I was confused by RippleNet, as I was stilling referring to the XRP Ledger as the Ripple Network, which it used to be called. Ripple used to be Ripple Labs used to be OpenCoin. XRP used to be called “ripples” and apparently don’t actually have a name, only a currency code.

I’m not of the opinion that how other people spend their crypto is any of my business. That said, Ripple has been very open & transparent about their XRP holdings, going so far as put them in escrow to help ease investor concerns.https://ripple.com/xrp/market-performance/ …

All crypto is created by code. Some code is designed to make people jump through hoops to obtain it and some code generates the crypto immediately. Ripple Consensus prevents double spending.https://code.likeagirl.io/xrp-is-a-cryptocurrency-like-the-uss-zumwalt-is-a-boat-3b25be5226b8?source=linkShare-c4107ebb5102-1521996267 …

I’m not a fan of Rippleco’s branding either but they didn’t do it to be malicious. There was no mining involved in the creation of $ XRP, so calling it “premined” adds to the confusion. Why invest in any crypto? (rhetorical)https://twitter.com/f0nta1n3/status/977943641548296198 …

People should definitely be asking @ Ripple hard questions, continuously. I have never shied away from being critical. I really want Rippleco and $ XRP to succeed and I have no problem throwing my 2 cents out there, even when unpopular. But what, exactly, is your hard question?
